quote: Today, all I wish to have is a drink between friends. A beginning. How we proceed is entirely up to you...
And if my wishes conflict with yours... ?
There will be no conflict.
And if I were to tell you to leave and never return to my world...

We would leave and never return. We are only here to help guide you... into a new era. I assure you we will not interfere with the natural development of your planet... that is, in fact, our Prime Directive.
I could infer from that directive that you do not intend to share all this extraordinary technology with us...
That is not the whole meaning... but it is part of it.
Is that your way of maintaining superiority?
To instantly transform a society with technology would be harmful and destructive...

You're right of course. I am overwhelmed, Captain Picard. Quite overwhelmed. I come home each night to a loving wife and two beautiful daughters... we eat the evening meal together as a family, I feel that's important... and they always ask me if I've had a good day.
How shall you answer them tonight, Chancellor?
Well, I'll have to say... this morning, I was the leader of the universe as I knew it... this afternoon, I am only a voice in a chorus. But I think it was a good day.
There are guards out there. You'll never escape that way.
I'm not afraid of you.
Good. Because there's nothing to be afraid of...
We shouldn't fear the unknown. We should embrace it.
Can you help me get out of here?
Are you really an alien? It's all right to tell me.
No, I'm not an alien...
I don't believe you. You are an alien.
Listen, I really have to leave...
I could divert the guard's attention. You might have a chance if you took the service exit down the hall to the left...
To the left. All right. Let's do it.
Why should I?
You know why. Because I don't belong here. Because I have to get back to my ship in space.
I believe you.
Now, will you help me?
If you make love to me.
What?
I've always wanted to make love with an alien.
Listen, Miss...
Lanel...
I really have to get going... all the... other aliens are expecting me...
It's not so much to ask. And then I'll help you escape.
It's not that easy. There are... differences... in the way my people make love.
I can't wait to learn.
But...
It's your only way out of here... my alien...
Something's happened to him... I think he's dead... hurry, go get help...
Okay...
Will I ever see you again... ?
I'll call you next time I'm passing through your star system.
Hey!
Stop him! Somebody stop him! He's escaping! The alien's escaping!
He's loose! Get him! Don't let him get away! Kill him! Stop him! Where's he going? He's dangerous! Block the exits! Knock him down! Kill him!
Leave him alone!
Stop it! All of you! Stop it now!
Have you all lost your minds?
They've aggravateded the injury to his telencephalin... he's bleeding internally...
Get him into a surgical cubicle... And call Central Security. This has gone too far.
Recommendation?
I don't know... it doesn't match anything...
Forget your training. What do you see?
The ichor pooling under the cranial bone... it seems to be exerting abnormal pressure. Ordinarily, I'd say we have to drill to relieve it.
Agreed. Suction...
Three-point-six aspiration drill.
I wonder what his own kind would do for him... I have to believe it'd be better than this...
Their leader, Picard, has made it clear that how we proceed is entirely our own decision...
You cannot possibly be suggesting surrender, Chancellor...
They are not hostile...
Mirasta, you are incredibly naive. Can you be so enraptured with the notion of space travellers that you are blind to the threat they represent... ?
I have seen their vessel, Krola... if they chose to be hostile, I don't think we would be standing here now...
Why should they use force when we are ready to lay down in fear...
I do not lay down in fear... to them or to you, Krola.

Chancellor, I mean no disrespect. But I have repeatedly warned you about your policies... taking us so quickly where we had no business going in the first place... New philosophies, new economics, new technologies. There are many people who still value our traditional way of life... and I for one am willing to die to defend it.
Open your eyes, Krola. We are part of a greater community now. We cannot ignore it.
You would ignore them... as they infiltrate and spy on us...
What are you saying, Krola?
We have captured one of their spies.
Chancellor, he is Captain Picard's first officer, Commander Riker.
You knew about this?
He has been missing for two days. I told Captain Picard not to discuss it because I was afraid this is exactly what would happen...
What else do you know, Mirasta? Everything.
They've been on our planet, observing us for several years...
Years... Imagine what they have done... influenced our young, stirred up dissent...
They were collecting information...
Where is this Commander Riker now?
You will not discuss this with Picard or the other aliens. If you are not comfortable with that, Mirasta, you may leave now.
He is at the Sikla Medical facility, recovering from surgery... he suffered head injuries in an attempt to escape. He will recover consciousness in a few hours.
Will he survive?
I didn't think he would have survived the injuries. The real question is can he survive the treatment..
I have to interrogate him before he dies.
At least give him time to regain some strength. Come back tomorrow.
It cannot wait until tomorrow.
Krola, we can get help from his ship. With their medical technology, he might recover.
We're not giving him back. He is the one advantage we have now. Use your drugs to revive him...
Those drugs increase cardial rate and vascular pressure... that's the last thing we want to do to him right now...
It will probably be enough to kill him... you can't do it...
Revive him.

I'm just a physician, Minister. I don't know much about affairs of state. But he is a living, intelligent being. I don't care if the Chancellor himself calls down here. I have sworn an oath to do no harm. And I will not.
Then I will find someone to replace you.
He won't have any trouble finding someone, you know.
Chancellor...
You are punctual, Captain.
I know how busy you are.
Do you?
I think you know a great deal more about me than I know about you.
In what respect?

I can't know what motivates you... how you make decisions... what value you place on life... you speak of trust and peace and working together to enter a new era... at the same time you conduct secret surveillance... posing as Malcorians...
Commander Riker.
Commander Riker.
Mirasta felt it would be a mistake to discuss...
Yes, she's tried to accept the responsibility.
You're right. It was my error, not hers.

Chancellor, no starship mission is more dangerous than first contact. We never know what we face when we open the door to a new world. How will we be greeted? What are the dangers? Centuries ago, a disastrous first contact with the Klingon Empire led to decades of war. It was decided then that we must do surveillance before making contact. It was a controversial decision. But I believe it prevents more problems than it creates.
I appreciate the logic of your position, Captain. But it would seem a full disclosure after contact would have been in order.

In time, there would have been full disclosure. I know I can only ask you to believe that. On some worlds, it is not even an issue. But here, everything our observers reported suggested the people of this world would almost certainly react negatively to our arrival. We could see our surveillance might even be interpreted as an act of aggression. I was hoping that we would find Commander Riker before you did... so the matter would not complicate our introduction. And it was a mistake.
A mistake I might have made in your place. I rather like it actually.
Like it?
That you make mistakes like any man.
Oh, I've made some fine ones in my time.
Will you release my officer?
We'll talk again later, Captain.
Enterprise, one to beam up.
Yes I understand.
I've been relieved of my duties... as I'm sure you already know. You are acting director of the facility, Nilrem.
Revive him.
Leave us.
I am Minister Krola from Internal Security. You are Riker, an alien...
Yes, we know.
Please. Bring my people here.
In time. In time. But first, I need to ask you some questions...
Thank you for seeing me.
If I did not depend so much on your expertise in space matters, I would have asked for your resignation.
I felt I was acting in the best interests of our people, Chancellor.
When you are selected to occupy this office, then you'll have the privilege of deciding the best interests of our people. Picard, I can excuse. But you, Mirasta, you should have trusted me.
Chancellor -- we must release Riker to Picard... Any hope for a relationship with these people depends on it...
I cannot afford to be the idealist you are, Mirasta.
Riker...
I am prepared to release Riker after we've interrogated him...

Are you prepared for him to die, Chancellor? His injuries are extremely serious. A mob at the medical facility almost killed him. Krola has ordered drugs to be used to revive him for questioning, drugs that are dangerous in his condition. Without medical aid from his ship, I believe Riker will not survive the day. You must tell Picard where he is.
You have lied since the moment of your capture... and I believe you are lying now, Commander.
We... are here on a mission of peace...
Such noble creatures.
Why do peaceful people develop such lethal weapons?
Or do you still insist it is a toy?
Yes, my experts were able to make it function. An interesting toy to be sure.
It is... for defense...

Perhaps, like many conquerors, you believe your goals to be benevolent. I cannot. For however you would describe your intentions, you still represent the end to my way of life. I cannot permit that to occur.
Eventually, Durken would choose to welcome your people with arms open and eyes closed. I must force him down another path.
When they find us, I will be dead, killed by your weapon. The lines will be drawn. A peaceful accord will no longer be an option.
No...
For my people.
Captain, Chancellor Durken has requested your immediate presence on the surface. It's in regard to Commander Riker.
Acknowledged, Lieutenant.
Life signs failing on one...
... he's dying, Nilrem... you can't just stand here... or can you... ?
What... ?
He shot him. The alien shot Krola...
I'm a physician... don't be frightened... What happened?
The... he shot him... with that thing...
Crusher to Picard.
Go ahead, Doctor.
Commander Riker is near death. But there is still brain activity... I've got to take him back to the ship...
Acknowledged.
Minister Krola has a phaser wound in his upper chest.
I should take him with us.
We'll meet you on the Enterprise.
Enterprise, five to beam up... directly to Sickbay... energize...
They're both going to be okay... we were able to stabilize Will... if we'd been any later...
Krola?
He was never in any real danger... the phaser was on stun...
Stun?
It is a defensive weapon. We do not use it to kill. Have you been able to ascertain what happened?
I have a good idea. Based on the angle of impact... it suggests that Krola had his right hand on the phaser when it went off...
They were struggling for the weapon?
Commander Riker was in no position to offer any kind of struggle, Chancellor.
Krola was trying to be a martyr... ?
Where is this?
(gently, with a sad smile) You are aboard the starship, my foolish old friend.
No. Chancellor... you must not... you must not pursue relations with them... you must not...
I know. I know.
But Chancellor...
Mirasta, it goes against every instinct in my being...

... but my people are not ready to accept what you represent. Everything that happened at the hospital proves it. Krola is the best evidence of all. We must slow down and allow all those like him to join us in the present before we move into the future.
But when we encounter other beings in space, our people must be ready...
The warp program will have to be delayed... we will divert more resources into education and social development to prepare for the day when we are ready.
Chancellor, I strongly disagree.
I know. Captain Picard, you once said that if I ask you to leave, you would without hesitation. I'm afraid I must ask you to do just that.
It is your decision, Chancellor. But I must say I regret that we won't have the opportunity of knowing your people better.
We are a good people, Captain. A society with much potential. Once we cross this threshold of space, we will have to give up the self-importance, the conceit that we are the center of the universe.
But this is not the time. For now, it is better that we continue to enjoy that sweet innocence.
But how can you keep us a secret... when so many have seen and heard so much?

The stories will be told for many years, I have no doubt... of the ship that made contact... of an alien who was held prisoner in a medical facility... there will be charges of a government cover-up... some of the witnesses will tell their tales and most people will laugh at them and go back and watch more interesting fiction on the daily broadcasts. It will pass.
I'm sorry to say... he's probably right.
Captain, I have one last request... take me with you.
She will be unhappy with the restrictions I must place on her at home, Captain.
We may not be back in your lifetime. And I have to believe that you are not fully prepared for the risks of space, Mirasta...
I have been prepared for the risks of space since I was nine years old sitting in a planetarium.
Mister Worf, to my Ready Room...
Escort Chancellor Durken to the transporter room, Lieutenant... and then assign quarters to Minister Yale. She'll be staying on board.
Aye, sir.
Until we return then...
With luck, we will both still be around to renew our friendship, Captain.

Captain's Log, Stardate 46041.1. We have located the U.S.S. Yosemite, a Starfleet science vessel sent to the Igo Sector to observe a remote plamsa streamer. The ship has not been heard from in several days.
Magnify.
The last report we have says they were observing the streamer at medium range. Maybe they went in for a closer look... got more than they bargained for.
Hail them.
No response.
Life signs?
Our scanners cannot penetrate the plasma streamer's distortion field.
Can we tractor the vessel out?
No, sir -- the ionic interference is too heavy.
I'll take a shuttle.
Too risky -- you could be pulled in, too. Bridge to Engineering -- Geordi, can we beam an Away Team onto the science ship?
We can beam them over there, Captain -- but with all this interference, we might not get a positive lock to bring them back.
Commander... what if we bridged our Transporter system with theirs? It might be enough to cut through the ionic field.
To do that, we'd have to activate the Yosemite's Transporters by remote...
No problem, sir. I can reconfigure their controller to accept commands from here.
Good idea, Reg. Captain, I think we can do it. We're gonna bridge the two Transporter systems.
Acknowledged. Meet Commander Riker in Transporter Room Three.
Aye sir. (to Barclay, on the move) Barclay -- I'll need a systems' engineer on this Away Team.
I'll ask Ensign Dern to join you.
I meant you, Barclay.
Shouldn't I stay here and set up the remote link?
Dern can handle that. Let's go.
Status, Mister O'Brien?
You're in for a bumpy ride, Commander.
I'll have to send you over one at a time... because of band-width limitations. And the transport cycle will take a bit longer.
How much longer?
Four, five seconds... about twice the normal time.
What do you... what exactly do you mean by a bumpy ride?
There may be a small amount of static charge accumulation. You'll feel a bit of tingling -- nothing to worry about.
Let's do it.
Engaging system interlock... Pattern buffers synchronized...
Phase transition coils at stand-by... Energizing.
He's there.
Engaging interlock... Buffers synched...
Energizing.
I'll go next.
Engaging interlock... Buffers synched...
Whoa, wait a minute... I'm reading an ionic fluctuation in the matter stream... No problem.
Okay... Energizing.
Barclay.
Aye sir...
Engaging interlock... Buffers in synch...
Phase coils...
I'm sorry -- I can't do this.
You were faced with a difficult transport, Reg. Anyone would have been apprehensive in that situation.
Tell that to Commander La Forge and the rest of the Away Team...
I'm sure they understand. As soon as you feel up to it, you can probably still join them --
No.
Reg... is there something you're not telling me?
Actually, this isn't the first time I've been... apprehensive. Every single time I've had to do it, I've had a certain feeling of... I guess you could call it... ... mortal terror.
I see. How long have you had this fear of transporting?
Why have you kept it a secret?
Why? My career in Starfleet would be over, that's why.
I doubt that.
I usually manage to avoid it somehow. You wouldn't believe how many hours I've logged on shuttlecrafts... The thought of being deconstructed molecule by molecule. It's more than I can stand...
Ever since I was a child, I've been scared to death that if I ever dematerialized... I wouldn't come back whole again. I know it sounds crazy.
There's nothing crazy about it, Reg -- you are being taken apart molecule by molecule. You're not the first person to have anxiety about transporting.
We can desensitize you to this type of fear. It's a slow and gradual process... but it works.
It does... how?
Well... the first step might be a relaxation technique. Like Plexing.
Plexing?
It's a Betazoid method. The next time you feel nervous about transporting, you would stimulate a neural pressure point -- like this...
There's a nerve cluster just behind the carotid artery -- it stimulates the part of the brain that releases natural endorphins.
Plexing... sounds easy enough...
You know, I feel better already. I can do this.
Reg... there's no need to rush...
No, no, no. We've talked before about confronting my fears. "The best way out is through." You said that once, remember?
I suppose I did...
I'm going to beam over there. I can do it.
No sign of survivors. No sign of a anyone.
Maybe they abandoned ship.
Unlikely. Both escape pods are still on board.
Well, there was an explosion in here. We know that much.
Any idea what caused it?
I've ruled out a reactor core failure... and there's no sign of a systems overload.
Blast analysis indicates the explosion originated...
...here. In the center of this transport chamber.
How is that possible? The Transporter is still functional.
Could someone have beamed an explosive device aboard?
Commander Riker...
Lieutenant Joshua Kelly -- he was the ship's engineer.
How did he die?
There's evidence of burns... but they don't look serious enough to have killed him... I'm going to have to take him back for an autopsy.
You're sure about this, sir?
I'm sure. Please proceed.
This'll only take a minute...
Should be a smooth ride over, sir.
Good... good...
I know how you feel about this, sir.
You... you're afraid of transporting?
No -- of arachnids. Spiders. Sickening, crawly little things, don't you think? All those legs...
They've never bothered me.
A few years back, I was called in to re-route an emitter array at a Starbase on Zayra Four. Turns out the entire system was infested with Talarian hook spiders. Ever see a Talarian hook spider?
Their legs are half a meter long. Anyway, I had a choice. Do I walk away and let the emitter blow itself to hell... or do I crawl into a Jeffries Tube with twenty hook spiders?
What happened?
It was the hardest thing I ever did. But I got through it. After that, I was never quite as afraid of spiders.
Thanks...
Energizing.
Welcome aboard, Reg. Ready to work?
Yes, sir.
Good. Start by downloading the ship's science logs. Over there...
Aye sir.
Still four members of the crew unaccounted for. You come up with anything?
I don't know how these fit in, but... I found them near the Transporter platform.
What are they?
They look like pieces of a standard sample container.
Take them back to the ship. We'll analyze them later.
Glad you could join us, Mister Barclay.
Me too, sir.
The Ferengi are claiming two of their freighters were destroyed by a Cardassian warship in your sector.
Is there any evidence to support this?
Although I'm loathe to believe the Ferengi about anything... there was evidence of Cardassian weapons.
If the Cardassians also attacked the Yosemite... it could indicate a large-scale movement into this sector.
I have an Away Team aboard the ship now. Their initial report indicates an explosion on board. But we're not sure if it was from an attack...
How long until you'll know?
A few hours. If it does look like the Cardassians, I'll contact you immediately.
Very well.
Bridge to Captain Picard.
Yes, Mister Data?
The Away Team is returning to the Enterprise.
Acknowledged. Have Commander Riker join me in my Ready Room as soon as he's on board.
Aye sir.
La Forge to Transporter Room Three.
I'm ready to go.
Stand by, Commander.
Barclay to Enterprise... One to beam back.
Stand by, sir.
You see, sir? That wasn't so bad, was it?
Captain's Log, supplemental. Our investigation has revealed there was an explosion aboard the Yosemite -- possibly the result of an attack. We are still analyzing data obtained by the Away Team.
Mission logs... science logs... medical logs -- they're all completely scrambled. It looks like the blast wiped out the ship's core memory.
We could try to reconstitute the data stream.
It's worth a try.
Commander... has anything... strange ever happened to you during transport?
Like what?
I don't know... anything out of the ordinary...
Not really...
This looks hopeless -- we're not gonna get anything from the logs...
Maybe this broken sample container I found can tell us something...
Right...
Let's try to get this thing back in one piece...
I mean -- have you ever seen anything?
Where?
In the... during transport.
Sometimes my VISOR picks up resonance patterns from the matter-energy conversion. It's actually kind of pretty. Why?
Just wondering...
Reg -- what are you getting at?
Do you think you saw something during transport?
When I was returning to the Enterprise... I could've sworn I saw something... in the matter stream.
Something?

There was phased matter all around... at first I thought it was some kind of energy discharge. But then it flew toward me... and touched my arm... But how could anything be in there... the molecules flying apart... half-phased... it's...
It's... impossible, isn't it?
We'd better check it out. When we're done here, let's run a full Transporter diagnostic. Alright?
Alright.
The confinement beam subsystems check out. So do the phase transition coils.
The pattern buffer's fine.
Emitter pad... targeting scanner -- they're all running normally. This system's clean... so is the science vessel's.
There's a lot of energy floating around in the beam. Maybe you saw a surge in the matter stream.
Yeah...
I'll run a scan on the Heisenberg compensators...
No... you've done more than enough already, Chief...
No problem at all. Why don't you give me a hand?
Maybe ignorance really is bliss...
Sir?
If I didn't know so much about these things... maybe they wouldn't scare me so much...

I can still remember the day in Doctor Olafson's class on Transporter Theory when he talked about the body being converted into billions of kiloquads of data... zipping through subspace... and I realized, there's no margin for error. One atom out of place and poof! You never come back... It's amazing people don't get lost all the time.
With all due respect sir -- I've been doing this for twenty-two years, and I haven't lost anybody yet.
Yes, but... you realize if these imaging scanners are off by even a thousandth of a percent --
That's why each pad has four redundant scanners. If any one scanner fails, the other three take over.
How many Transporter accidents have there been in the last ten years, Reg? Two... three? What about the millions of people who transport every day without a problem?
I've... I've heard about problems... what about... Transporter Psychosis?
Transporter Psychosis -- there hasn't been a case of that in over fifty years. Not since they perfected multiplex pattern buffers.
Transporting really is the safest way to travel, Reg.
I want to take a closer look at those burns. Take a tissue sample.
Yes, Doctor.
Damage to the epidermis only... Initiate a circulatory probe.
Doctor Crusher...
His heart is beating.
Cardio-stimulator -- now.
It's gone.
Neuro-electrical activity in the cerebral cortex.
Nothing.
Now the respiratory system's active. What the hell's going on...
Endocrine system's functioning... now the lymphatic system... the pancreas...
Just water, please.
Thanks.
Water, ten degrees celsius.
Computer... access Starfleet Medical Data Base. Tell me about... describe the disorder known as... Transporter Psychosis.
Transporter Psychosis was diagnosed in the year twenty-two-oh-nine by researchers on Delinia Two --
No, no... stop. All I need is the... what causes it?
It is caused by a breakdown of neuro-chemical molecules during transport, affecting the body's motor functions, autonomic systems, and the brain's higher reasoning centers.
What are the symptoms?
Victims suffer from paranoid delusions... multi-infarct dementia... hallucinations...
Hallucinations? What kind of hallucinations?
Victims experience somatic, tactile and visual hallucinations, accompanied by psychogenic hysteria.
Peripheral symptoms include sleeplessness... accelerated heart-rate...
Diminished eyesight, leading to acute myopia... painful spasms in the extremities...
And in most cases, dehydration.
Computer... what is the treatment for Transporter Psychosis?
There is no known treatment.
The autopsy showed residual ionization in every one of Lieutenant Kelly's systems. I think that's what caused the muscular and systemic contractions.
Where did this ionization come from?
There's evidence of electrical burns on the victim's body... as if she were exposed to ionized gas... or high energy plasma.
Plasma? There's no way they could've been exposed... unless it was matter from the streamer...
Is there any evidence of a hull breach... could plasma from the streamer have found its way into the ship?
No... (gets an idea, to Data) Data, what's the report on that broken sample container?
The analysis of the fragments is not yet complete.
Captain -- if there's evidence of similar ionization in those fragments... it could mean they tried to beam aboard material from the streamer...
And if the plasma exploded... that would explain a few things. Let me know when the analysis is complete.
Aye sir.
From the looks of these fracture patterns, I'd say the explosive force came from within the container.
The container does show evidence of residual ionization. I believe your hypothesis was correct. It was being used to store high energy plasma.
So they were collecting samples from the plasma streamer... But they were using the proper container. How could it have exploded?
Perhaps we should try to recreate their experiment to see what happens when matter is beamed aboard under similar conditions.
Good idea. Let's prepare a new container. Reg, I don't want to take any chances -- start setting up a level five containment field here in Engineering.
Aye sir...
Are you having trouble with your eyesight, Mister Barclay?
No... thank you.
May I have a word with you, Geordi? It concerns Lieutenant Barclay.
What is it?
He appears to be inordinately preoccupied with his physiological condition. I have seen him check his pulse rate, as well as his visual acuity several times in the last twenty minutes.
Reg...
Yessir?
Are you alright?
Just fine, sir.
You look a little pale.
I do?
It's been a long couple of days, Reg. Why don't you get some rest. We've got everything under control here.
I'll do that, sir. Thank you.
La Forge to Counselor Troi.
Go ahead, Commander.
Counselor... do you have a minute?
Lieutenant Barclay, I've been calling you, why haven't you responded --
Reg, what are you doing?
Walking.
I can see that. Where are you going?
Nowhere. I just don't get to these decks very often. There's Stellar Cartography -- I thought that was on Deck Eleven.
Mister Barclay...
I was... I was having trouble sleeping. I'm just trying to wear myself out. That's a perfectly normal thing to be doing, isn't it?
Commander La Forge said you seemed very nervous this morning.
I'm always nervous. Everyone knows that.
He also mentioned that you said you saw something in the Transporter beam.
I was wrong. They checked the Transporter and there wasn't... there was nothing there. I imagined the whole thing.
You don't sound very convinced of that...
Counselor, I appreciate your concern... but I'd rather not continue this conversation. I'm... I'm feeling perfectly fine.
Mister Barclay, you are exhausted and highly agitated.
And I cannot allow a member of this crew to endanger himself and others. I think --
I'm not endangering anyone and I wish you would --
I think it's in your best interest to take a leave of absence. Reg -- I'm temporarily relieving you of duty.
Fine... fine... do what you have to do, Counselor...
Computer... more birds.
End stress reduction program.
Water.
Specify temperature.
I don't care -- just give me water!
Calm... stay calm... Computer -- let's try music... something soothing.
Barclay to Chief O'Brien.
O'Brien here.
I need your help. Would you meet me in Transporter Room Three... ?
Sir, begging your pardon -- but couldn't this wait til morning?
No...
Chief... I've just... I've been reviewing the transport logs... What are these... energy variations that keep appearing? There was one when I transported to the science ship... see?
They're just ionic fluctuations, sir. A result of our interlock with the Yosemite's transporter system.
A fluctuation occurred while I was inside the matter stream... ?
It's nothing to worry about, sir.
I need you to transport me to the science ship... and directly back again. And while I'm in the beam... can you recreate one of those ionic fluctuations... ?
I guess so... but if you don't mind my asking, sir... what for?
I need to... Commander La Forge wants some tricorder readings of those fluctuations.
We can do it from right here.
No, I... the Transporter sensors may not be sensitive enough...
I'm giving you an order, Mister O'Brien.
Aye sir.
If you don't mind my making an observation... You forgot to bring a tricorder.
Either there's something in there... or I'm going crazy. I've got to know. You can understand that, can't you?
Yes sir, I can.
Stand by, sir...
I want you to wake the senior staff.
Then I saw it again -- just twenty minutes ago. The same exact thing moving around in the Transporter beam.
Let me get this straight -- you think it was alive?
It was dark and distorted... and it had what looked like... a mouth...
A mouth?
I don't see anything wrong with his arm.
Reg -- why did you wait so long to tell anybody about your arm?
Well... I thought I was hallucinating. I thought it was... that I had... Transporter Psychosis...
But now I know I don't. I know what I saw in there... was real. I was the only one to experience an ionic fluctuation during transport... maybe that explains why that's why no one else saw it.
We ran a full diagnostic on the Transporter system yesterday, Captain. It checked out fine.
Number One?
We've been conducting intensive scans of the entire binary star system. No sign of any life forms.
Mister Barclay, I understand you've been under a considerable amount of strain the past couple of days. Isn't it possible you simply imagined --
I know what you're going to say, sir. And I realize... I know I've been acting strangely. But you've got to believe me. I wouldn't have called you in here if I weren't absolutely certain.
Commander La Forge, get Chief O'Brien -- take the Transporter system apart piece by piece if you have to. Mister Worf -- maintain a level three security alert until further notice.
Aye, sir.
I'll run a micro-cellular scan on Mister Barclay's arm. It'll take some time -- but if there's something wrong, I'll find it.
Keep me apprised. Dismissed.

I'm reading minute levels of residual ionization in the sub-dermal tissue of his left arm. The patterns correspond exactly to the ones we measured in Lieutenant Kelly's body... and in the sample container from the science ship. There's no question -- you've been exposed to the same high energy plasma they were.
So... something did happen to me in the Transporter beam?

It's too early to draw conclusions... you might've been exposed to something on the science ship. But you did say something touched your left arm during transport... and that's where the ionization is focused...
Does this ionization pose a threat to Mister Barclay?
It might. I'll need to run a base-pair correlation to look for signs of DNA break-down.
Sir... Commander La Forge and I were planning to recreate the circumstances of the explosion on the Yosemite... that might give us some answers. Permission to continue with the experiment?
Granted. Tell Chief O'Brien to take all primary Transporters off-line. I don't want to risk any further... contaminations. And make sure you take the necessary safety precautions.
Aye sir.
I want you to wear this monitoring-device. It'll signal me at the slightest sign of increased ionization.
Yes, Doctor.
Structural reinforcement is at two hundred forty percent.
Activating containment field...
That should do it. Okay, Reg -- we've locked onto the coordinates of the plasma streamer. You can beam aboard a sample.
Aye sir.
Okay... what would they have done first?
A standard analysis begins with a resonance frequency scan.
Sounds like a good place to start. Let's do it.
Initiating resonance sweep. Frequency range at --
Check the containment field.
Field is at maximum limits, sir. But it is holding.
My VISOR's picking up bio-magnetic energy... highly complex patterns... I think these things are alive. Reg...
Reg?
Reg!
Life forms?
That is correct. They appear to be quasi-energy microbes that exist within the distortion field of the plasma streamer -- which made them undetectable to our sensors.
They didn't come out until we tried to run the resonance frequency scan. Apparently, they didn't like it too much. They reacted by shattering the sample container.
Which caused a plasma explosion similar to the one on the science ship...
Exactly. We think one or more of the microbes may have gotten into the Transporter system -- and are still caught inside the buffer. It probably explains what you saw in there...
But... what I saw was much larger than a microbe...
Normal spatial relationships, such as size, are often distorted within the matter stream.
Some of these microbes are also in your body, Reg.
Inside me?
They were in Lieutenant Kelly's body as well... that's what caused the contractions during the autopsy.
Is that what killed him?
Yes... But now that we've identified the microbes, we can start trying to eliminate them. I'm going to run a full spectrum antigen series... if that doesn't work, I'll try an imaging probe...
But... isn't there a way to... to... to force these things out of me?
The bio-filter should've screened them out... but it didn't...
The microbes exist simultaneously as both matter and energy. The bio-filters cannot distinguish them from the matter stream.
Right... but -- if we held Barclay suspended in mid-transport... at the point where matter starts to lose molecular cohesion...
The molecules would begin to emit nucleonic particles. We might be able to derive a pattern the computer could recognize...
... and reprogram the bio-filters to screen out the microbes. Reg, I think this'll work.
Suspend me... I don't like the sound of that...
We'd have to hold you in there for a while...
How long?
Thirty or forty seconds... it's hard to tell. But I think it would be safe...
But... if I'm in the matter stream too long...
Your pattern would degrade to the point where your signal would be permanently lost.
Your pattern might degrade to the point where your signal would be permanently lost.
This has been the thing I've been afraid of all my life... that I'd go in and not come back...
But I guess... if I'm ever going to confront my fear, it might as well be now...
After fifteen seconds or so in the beam, you may start to feel lightheaded. Try to stay calm... and it's important you don't move around too much.
Right.
Initializing the back-up pattern buffer. Holding at stand by...
You ready, Reg?
Energize.
Molecular resolution at sixty percent... engaging static mode... his pattern is locked and holding...
Starting bio-filter scan...
Signal's holding...
The imaging scanners still aren't isolating the microbes...
I'll try increasing molecular dispersion...
But -- his signal resolution's dropped to fifty-five percent...
Don't worry -- I can hold him together...
His signal resolution's down to fifty percent... we need to bring him back...
I know, I know... just give me one more second... We need more dispersion... increase phase-transition frequency...
Aye, sir...
The imaging scanners are actuating...
Got it... pattern acquisition... Positive.
Programming bio-filter...
This won't hurt a bit, Reg...
I'm reading a ninety-two percent increase in mass, sir!
Something's in the beam with him... Security to Transporter Room Three!
I'm setting up a force field around the chamber...
(to O'Brien, on the move) Drop the force field.
There are more of them in the beam... you have to grab them and hold on...
Reg, what happened?
When I saw there was more than one of them... I thought... maybe the other crew was trying the same thing we were...
We were infected with something... Lieutenant Kelly... tried to reprogram the bio-filter...
It looks like he increased molecular dispersion past the integrity point... your patterns were lost in the beam.
The residual energy from the plasma streamer... it must've amplified the charge in the buffer... enough to keep your patterns from degrading...

Captain's Log, Stardate 46043.6. The reprogrammed bio-filter was effective in removing the alien microbes from Mister Barclay and the four crewmembers. The microbes have been returned to the plasma streamer.
Chief...
Lieutenant -- glad you could make it.
You know, I think this is the first time we've ever talked, outside the Transporter Room.
Well... to be honest, I always avoided you.
Why?
Because... you run the Transporters, and I hate transporters...
At least... I used to...
So what's in the box?
I thought you might like to meet Christina.
Christina -- Lieutenant Barclay.
Your... pet spider.
Lycosa tarantula. Don't worry, she won't bite.
It's... she's... very... large.
I found her on Titus Four... almost stepped on her by accident.
I'll get us a couple of drinks. Keep an eye on her, will you?
Sure...
Um... Chief...
Captain's log, stardate 45494.2. We are investigating a series of subspace signals that may indicate intelligent life in the Epsilon Silar System. We will be within sensor range in three hours...

The characteristic response to the Kriskov Gambit is to counter with an el-Mitra Exchange -- particularly since I have already taken both your rooks. By missing that opportunity, you have left your king vulnerable.
We'll see...
As you wish.
Check.
Intriguing. You have devised a completely unanticipated response to a classic attack. You will checkmate my king in seven moves.
Chess isn't just a game of gambits and ploys -- it's also a game of intuition.
You are a challenging opponent.
Thanks. But don't think a compliment's going to get you out of our bet. You owe me one Samarian Sunset. Served in the traditional style. As only you can make it, Data...
I will honor our agreement.
Raise your arm out to the side.
Is that it?
I'm afraid so.
You can put your arm down now.
What do you think?
I think it looks like you tucked when you should have flattened out.
Something like that...
Turn your head to the left.
Some tearing in the ligaments -- nothing we can't take care of.
Good.
If I remember correctly, the last time you graced my sickbay, you were diving off the "Cliffs of Heaven" on Cirrus Four. Holodeck program 47-C.
Same thing. Only that time, I flattened out when I should have tucked.
As your Doctor, I'd like to recommend the Emerald Wading Pool on Sumiko Three. It's a lot safer.
Navigators on this ship have been doing flight handling assessments the same way for years, Ensign...
And I've found a better way...
Bridge. Do you mind if we discuss changes in procedure before you make them?
If I had come to you in advance and asked you if I could do it my way...
I would have said...
"No".
Or maybe "yes".
The point is -- I never got that chance.
The point is... with all due respect... you're trying to turn me into your idea of a model officer.
Ensign... the rules on this ship don't change because Ro Laren decides they do.
We are picking up a subspace signal, Captain. Sensors show a small space craft ahead.
The configuration is unfamiliar -- nothing in our database comes close.
Within visual range.
On screen.
Analysis, Mister Worf.
No discernable armament. Reading one life-form aboard.
Hail the vessel.
No response, Captain.
We're being scanned... but it's not like any sensor system I've ever seen... Should we raise shields?
No. We'll start this off with a show of good faith.
Sir, the scans are now matching the frequencies of our optical data network.
It could be an attempt to access our computer system.
Scanning intensity has increased by fifteen hundred percent.
Shields up.
One Samarian Sunset, served in the traditional style.
It's beautiful.
I hope you enjoy it.
I hope you enjoy it.
The scanning signal has penetrated our shields...
Our computers are going down!
Take evasive action --
-- The helm's not responding!
What happened?
What the hell...
I don't know who any of you are.
Neither do I... I don't even remember who I am...
It looks like we're all in the same boat.
Make that -- "on the same starship."
But who are we? What are we doing here?
It looks like I'm the pilot.
We're not going anywhere now. The helm's dead.
But you still know how to work it.
Yes...
This console has a tactical configuration.
Phaser power status, intruder scan, torpedo guidance...
They do not appear to be operable.
Clearly, we still possess certain skills -- we seem to know how to operate this vessel. But our identities have somehow been erased, or suppressed.
We are on the bridge -- there's a good chance this is our ship.
And it looks like you're the leader.
We should not jump to conclusions. I am... decorated as well.
Determining our command structure isn't crucial right now. Finding out who we are, and what we're doing out here is.
But how did this happen? What did this to us?
More like -- who did this to us?
I've got some intermittent sensor readings here... the scan keeps repeating itself -- like it's stuck. But it looks like there's metallic debris right in front of us. Distance: seventeen kilometers.
The remains of another ship?
That's a good possibility.
Perhaps we were engaged in battle.
If they stunned us with some kind of bioelectric field -- that might have wiped out our memories.
Then we fired back. Destroyed them.
If this presumption is correct, we may have sustained other damage. Computer... status report.
No voice interface...
No interface, period.
Hey -- got something.
I've accessed the basic system directories.
Can you give us a general status report?
... Life-support systems are fully operational throughout the ship. Navigation and propulsion... Off line.
What about communications?
Completely disrupted.
That rules out a distress signal.
If we even knew where to send it.
Do we have an onboard communication system?
We do now.
I suggest we use it. Our ship must have a crew. They may still have their memories.
We should be careful what we say... there could be a boarding party somewhere on the ship.
Bridge to all personnel. Select a representative from your group to contact the bridge and report on your status.
Remain where you are. Stay calm. Bridge out.
Well, that helps a lot.
Report on our "status"? I wonder if every one else is in the same condition we are.
It hurts...
Thanks...
I didn't even think -- I just knew how to use it.
At least I've got an idea of what I'm doing here.
What about me? I'm a patient in a bathing suit... That doesn't say much.
No, it doesn't.
Do you have any clothes around here I could borrow? At least until I figure out where the swimming pool is?
Yes?
We've heard from all decks -- there are over a thousand people on board. Everyone's had their memories affected in the same way we have.
I have completed a survey of our tactical systems. We are equipped with ten phaser banks, two hundred seventy five photon torpedoes, and a high capacity shield grid.
We're a battleship.
It appears so...
This turbolift system will give us access to the rest of the ship...
That sounds like the next logical step... we should start with the most crucial area first...
Main engineering. Deck thirty-six. I'm on my way.
Hey, hold on, we've gotta coordinate our efforts here...
I just need to do something...
Look, I feel the same way... we all do... but if anything's gonna get done here...
I know, I just... It's really an ugly feeling... I don't like being so... out of control.
Well, we're all gonna have to depend on each other to get through this, okay?
Okay.
We're going to search the ship.
Very well. Proceed.
I'll go with you. I want to get my hands on the computer core. See if we can reestablish control from there.
I've accessed the optical data network for the engineering core. I can monitor every system that's routed through here.
Warp and impulse drive are reading within tolerance levels. So are all the tactical arrays... defensive and offensive...
Everything looks functional... now if we could just access the control systems we could get them up and running.
According to the schematics, the engineering computer core access is down that corridor.
Weapons, propulsion and shields are the priorities. We might be in danger of another attack.
That's where I'll start.
Let's begin our crew survey on decks five through ten.
Alright. Good luck.
You too.
When you've got those systems going, try for the personnel files. It would be nice if we all had names...
So far, our survey team has found no deaths or injuries among the crew. The shuttlecraft are operational, as are the transporters.
But no one they've talked to knows any more about their identities than we do.
Engineering is working on accessing the control systems. As soon as the ship is operational, we must make it combat-ready.
I would recommend that before we prepare for combat, we try to access the ship's logs. Discover who we are and what our purpose here might be.
I disagree. We must first make ourselves ready for battle. That is the highest priority.
Engineering to the bridge.
Go ahead, engineering.
I've regained control of propulsion, navigation, weapons, and communications. We'll be able to tie them into the bridge in just a few minutes.
Well done.
We are ready.
The question is -- for what?
The phasers are operational.
We now have full tactical control.
We should run a complete diagnostic of all command systems.
A full diagnostic would require us to take our systems off-line. We would be defenseless.
If we're going to trust our lives to these systems, we should make certain they aren't going to fail.
The computer was damaged. Some processors might still be down...
Proceed with the diagnostic.
What have you found, Doctor?
Not much. The brain scans I've run are unusual, but they show no damage to the hippocampus. That suggests we still have our long-term memories... but somehow they're being blocked.
Is it possible to bypass the normal pathways? To get at those memories in some other way?
That's what I'm hoping. What I need now is to see some normal brain scans for comparison. Is there any chance I could get the crew's medical files?
We are currently running a full diagnostic. Computer resources are limited.
The medical records will be our next priority.
Thank you.
I guess these are my quarters. But I don't remember anything.
If it's any comfort, everybody's in the same situation. Stay put for now... we'll be back in touch.
Okay, sir. Thanks.
That's all I need for now.
Well, that's it for the living quarters on this deck. What's next?
There's a large room up ahead. On the diagram, it's called "Ten Forward."
Let's go.
If everything was back the way it was supposed to be -- what do you think you'd be doing right now... ?
Having a lot more fun than searching the ship, I'd imagine.
Fun?
With that holodeck we just saw, I bet I could conjure up an interesting program or two...
Now, that's disappointing...
Why?
You don't strike me as a man who needs a holodeck to have a good time.
Who reported to the bridge from this group?
I did.
Have you found anything that might give us some insight into what happened?
Not specifically. But there are two things that seem unusual...
The bartender is an artificial lifeform.
Is there something I could get you? A beverage of your choice?
No, thank you.
I'm fine.
Your memories are gone as well?
The databanks that would identify who I am are not functioning.
You were going to mention something else?
I don't know if this means anything... but I seem to have an ability that the others don't. I have a very strong sense of what people are feeling... at times it's almost --
Is something wrong?
No... it's just... for a moment... you seemed familiar.
You remember me?
Not exactly... I mean, I don't know who you are... but there's something about you...
Bridge to survey team.
Survey team here.
We have accessed the personnel files. Report to the bridge immediately.
On our way.
Computer -- give me a biographical listing of all personnel responsible for primary operation of the ship.
A full biographical listing is not available.
Is there any list of the ship's senior officers?
The crew manifest is available.
That's better than nothing. Give me the crew manifest.
Commanding Officer, Captain Jean-Luc Picard.
Executive Officer... Commander Keiran MacDuff.

Second Officer... Commander William Riker. Operations Officer... Lieutenant Commander Data. Chief Medical Officer... Doctor Beverly Crusher. Ship's Counselor, Lieutenant Commander Deanna Troi. Chief Engineer... Lieutenant Commander Geordi La Forge. Security Chief... Lieutenant Worf. Helm Officer... Ensign Ro Laren.
Commander MacDuff... Please see to it that all other officers who were listed report to the bridge.
Aye, sir.
Your next priority is to retrieve any information you can regarding this ship's mission.
Contact the operations officer to assist you.
He's in Ten-Forward -- waiting tables.
I regret my recent behavior. I assumed an attitude of authority that was... unwarranted.
We're all doing the best we can in a difficult situation. Think nothing more of it.
Thank you... Captain.
We haven't finished a full search of the computer records. But we've found out quite a bit.
This vessel is named the Enterprise. We are part of an organization called the United Federation of Planets. The Federation is currently in a state of war.
With whom?
The Lysian Alliance. They're a genocidal race determined to destroy us. The war's been going on for years.
Starfleet Command believes the Lysians have a new weapon that has shifted the balance of power in their favor.
Over the last two months, fourteen Federation ships have been captured -- apparently very easily -- and the crews imprisoned on Lysia.
What do we know about this weapon?

Our scientists theorize that the Lysians are using an energy wave -- either plasma based or a subspace interference pattern. The weapon severly disrupts a starship's computer systems and the mental functioning of the crew.
That's what happened to us...
Commander, is there any record of our current mission?
Yes, sir.
We're approximately here... We've been ordered to cross into Lysian territory... ... and destroy their Central Command.
This is it -- the nerve-center of the Lysian military operation.
Captain, there's been a great deal of damage to our computer system. Maybe we're not getting accurate information.
What are you suggesting?
That we get confirmation of this mission from our headquarters.
If we use subspace radio we will be detected --
But there may be thousands of lives at stake --
Our orders specifically require us to maintain radio silence.
Our mission is part of a highly coordinated effort to put an end to the war. There are other vessels on other fronts, all working according to an intricate plan.
We're the lynch pin to the operation. If we don't destroy the Central Command -- the entire effort will fail.
Captain, our choice is clear.
Commander MacDuff -- set a course for the Lysian Central Command.
These are your quarters.
Thanks for the help.
Come in for a minute.
Recognize anything?
It might as well belong to someone else.
Nothing feels right... this room, the ship... most of all this war we're fighting...
I don't imagine war ever feels right.
I suppose that's true...
What is it?
That same feeling... you seem familiar... you're the only thing that does.
Can you remember anything specific?
I don't know...
It's more like remembering an emotional image... feelings that are somehow associated with you...
I hope they're good feelings...
Yes... they are...
This entire situation is... a little unnerving...
It's been a long day. We've all been through a lot.
Yes. We certainly have.
I'll see you tomorrow. Good night.
Hi.
I know I didn't get the wrong room.
I didn't like the way mine was decorated. Besides, I have a funny feeling maybe I spend most of my off hours here.
Really?
For all we know, you and I could be married.
For all we know, you and I could hate each other.
That's kind of exciting, isn't it? Because we just don't know.
We might regret this.
Regret what? Aren't you being a little presumptuous?
Like I said -- I just didn't like the way my quarters were decorated.
Maybe we should switch quarters.
Maybe we should stay right here and see what happens.
What if I snore in my sleep?
What makes you think you're going to get any sleep?
Captain, we have crossed the Lysian border.
Ensign, take us out of warp. Three-quarters impulse.
Yes, sir.
Mister Worf, maintain a continuous sensor sweep.
Aye, Captain.
How long till we reach their central command?
At our current speed, approximately thirty-seven hours.
Captain, I am picking up a vessel directly ahead.
Can you identify?
The ship matches the Starfleet description of a Lysian Destroyer. A short-range attack vessel... with disruptor-style weapons, and a standard crew of fifty-three.
Within visual range.
On screen.
The destroyer is increasing its speed. They are moving to intercept.
Evasive maneuver sequence delta.
Yes, Sir.
They are matching our manuevers...
Activating phaser arrays... Ready to fire, Sir.
Stand by.
Captain, our orders were to destroy all Lysian warships.
I'm aware of that, Commander. Tactical analysis, Mister Data.
The destroyer has minimal shields. Their disruptor capacity appears to be only two point one megajoules.
They're no match for the Enterprise.
Captain -- the destroyer is hailing us.
Open a channel --
--No!
Their new weapon. Whatever it was that wiped out our computers and our memories. Maybe this is how they do it -- over communication channels.
It is conceivable, sir.
It's also possible that they simply want to talk to us. I think we should respond.
They are hailing us again.
If you're wrong, it could mean our destruction. I don't think we can take that risk.
Captain, The Lysians have stopped transmitting. They are powering up their disruptors. They have locked onto us, sir...
Full shields.
Shields up.
Captain... ?
Return fire.
The ship has been destroyed.
Maintain our course, Ensign. Increase to three quarters impulse.
Yes, Sir.
Well done, Captain.
The Lysian Central Command would have received any transmission from the destroyer by now.
They're going to be on alert.
I recommend a randomly vectored approach to our target. It would be our best chance of avoiding any pursuit.
Agreed.
Doctor, the success of this mission would be far more likely if we had our memories back. Is there anything you can do?
I found several cases resembling our condition in the medical index. The causes are different, but the cure is similar in each case.
Could the same treatment work for us?
That's my hope. It involves increasing the activity of the medial temporal region of the brain. Using short term memory synapses to retrieve long term memory.
When can you start?
As soon as our medical records become available. It would be too dangerous to attempt treatment without them.
Mister La Forge?
Data and I ran into some trouble accessing the medical file areas in the computer. But with a little time, I'm pretty sure we can get there. Three hours, maximum.
Proceed.
I'm still hitting a file wall... I don't get it.
There appears to be a command path discontinuity. I shall attempt to rewrite the locator subroutine.
You must have been one hell of a bartender.
It's too bad there aren't any more of you around. We could certainly use the help.
Yes.
I wonder why you're the only one on board?
I have expended a great deal of thought with respect to my apparent uniqueness among the crew.
Any conclusions?
Several possibilities suggest themselves.
I may represent an entire race of artificial lifeforms. If so, there may be a home planet for others of my kind -- a shared history and a culture of which I am not presently aware.
Then again, you could've been built just for this ship.
I have considered that possibility as well. It may also be the case that every starship in the Federation is equipped with an artificial lifeform such as myself.
It that's true, you might all even look alike. A standard issue android. Hard to construct -- so only one allowed per vessel. Maybe you all get together for android holidays...
There is another possibility. Perhaps my origin was unique. In that case... I am alone.
We have accessed the information storage area. But considerable damage has been done to the files themselves.
The mission reports are gone.
As are the crew records, and the personal logs.
So are the medical records.
Come in.
I'm restless. Mind if I visit for a while?
Please...
What's wrong?
Everything. Everytime I think about this war, our mission... I feel a sense of panic. Like a hand is closing around my throat.
You're never gonna feel good about this war. None of us will. But we've got to finish our mission.
I've been doing a little research. Learning about someone named William Riker.
And what have you discovered?
He's a musician, for one thing.
Very impressive.
Nobody could have been more surprised than me.
What else has your research uncovered about William Riker?
Let's see... He's athletically inclined... loves to mountain climb. He was born in a place called Alaska. He likes exotic foods... spends his vacation time on a planet called Risa...
"Ode to Psyche." John Keats.
Open it.
"To Will... All My Love, Deanna."
It could explain the familiar feeling you have...
I... don't know what to think.
Come in.
Hello, Counselor.
Ensign.
I'm not interrupting anything?
I was just visiting. We'll talk again soon, Commander.
Of course. Thank you, Counselor.
Bye...
What was that all about?
Just talking about the situation we're all in...
Good...
Because I have the feeling I used to be the jealous type.
What bothers me, Captain, is how specific the damage is. Any records of a personal nature, any files that could tell us more about who we are -- those are the ones that are gone.
That's a little too selective for coincidence.
As selective as what was done to our own memories. Our skills still in place -- but personal knowledge unavailable.
It's consistent with what we know about the new Lysian weapon.
Doctor, is it absolutely necessary for you to see the medical files before you attempt a treatment?
No. But it would be dangerous without them.
I think that's a risk we have to take --
(beating him to the punch) -- Captain, I volunteer for the procedure.
That's strange. The diencephalic activity is exactly the same. There should be some increase. Let's try broadening the band width.
Go to thirty point one.
Raise the frequency as well. Increase by thirty-three percent...
Something's wrong with the sequencing program!
Kieran. Kieran.
I'm alright.
What happened?
I don't know. Something went wrong with the sequence initiator. We're lucky we didn't lose you. Did any of this work? Do you remember anything about yourself?
I'm sorry, Doctor.
It's back to square one.
Enter.
You wanted to see me, Captain?
Yes, Commander. Sit down.
I find myself with grave concerns about our mission.
Concerns... as to its success?
No. I have more fundamental doubts...
Whether or not this mission is justified.
I've been asking myself the same thing. But I'm sure our superiors feel their orders are justified.
Orders which we cannot even verify.
(reluctantly concluding) Orders we cannot ignore.

But I also can't ignore the fact that we greatly outclassed the only enemy vessel we've encountered. And that every possible shred of information which could shed some light on our situation has been conveniently eliminated.
I feel as though I've been handed a weapon, pushed into a room and told to shoot a stranger.
I need a moral context to justify that action. And I don't have one. I'm not satisfied simply following orders. I want to know that what I am doing is right.
So do I. I'd feel a lot better about this if all the questions were answered. And if you want to abandon our mission until our memories return -- it's your choice.
But I must ask you... is it right to risk prolonging this war... to allow the needless deaths of thousands on both sides... solely on the basis of our moral discomfort?
Captain, we are approaching the Lysian system.
Decrease to one quarter impulse.
Yes, sir.
The Central Command is directly ahead. Still beyond weapon range.
Red Alert. Battle stations. Bring us to attack posture, Mister Worf.
Aye, Captain.
Sensors show several objects in our path. They are twenty-nine meters in length and are unmanned.
According to Starfleet records, they're sentry pods. Programmed to defend their Central Command.
I'm reading forty-seven of them around the perimeter.
Tactical analysis, Mister Data.
The pods are equipped with fusion generated pulse lasers, and minimal shielding.
Not much power there...
Forward shields on maximum. Lock phasers on the sentry pods and prepare to return fire.
Shields up, phasers locked on targets.
Full impulse. Take us straight through them.
We are through the perimeter.
This is too easy.
We have yet to encounter any battleships. They may lie ahead.
